testthat part of the tidyverse
  • Reference
  • News

Expectation class.

You generate an expectation object with expectation(), and signal an expectation with expect(). If you're making your own expectation function, you'll typically call expect(condition, "failure message"). See the source code for the built-in expectations for details.

expectation(type, message, srcref = NULL)

expect(exp, ..., srcref = NULL)

quasi_label(quo, label = NULL)

is.expectation(x)

Arguments

message

A text description of failure
srcref

Source reference, if known
quo, label

make_label is used to generate informative labels for expressions. quo should be created with rlang::enquo(), making it possible to use unquoting to generate informative labels when running multiple tests in a function or for loop.
x

object to test for class membership
passed

a single logical value indicating whether the test passed (TRUE), failed (FALSE), or threw an error (NA)

Contents

  • Arguments

testthat is a part of the tidyverse, an ecosystem of packages designed with common APIs and a shared philosophy. Learn more at tidyverse.org.
